channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Justice Dept. Said to Have Told Trump Lawyers He May Have More Documents
item.description: The move underscores the skepticism among investigators about the former president’s cooperation with the effort to retrieve government material, and it exposed a rift among his lawyers.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Schmidt, Maggie Haberman and Katie Benner
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Justice Department’s continued effort to retrieve more documents from former President Donald J. Trump has led to a rift among his lawyers.

item.title: Biden Pardons Thousands of People Convicted of Simple Marijuana Possession
item.description: The move represents a fundamental change in America’s response to a drug that has been at the center of a clash between culture and policing for more than a half-century.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: Protesters outside the White House in 2016. President Biden said on Thursday that he has asked the attorney general to review how marijuana is legally categorized.

item.title: Russia Lashes Out in Ukraine, Raising Question of What’s Next
item.description: Facing battlefield setbacks and domestic criticism, the Kremlin has escalated its war, claiming ownership of a nuclear plant and launching more attacks on Ukrainian cities.
item.dc:creator: Richard Pérez-Peña, Carly Olson and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Ukrainian firefighters battled a blaze after a strike in Zaporizhzhia on Thursday.

item.title: Ukrain Police Find Bodies of 534 Civilians in Recaptured Territory
item.description: The police have discovered 22 locations that they suspect were used as torture chambers in areas recently reclaimed from Russian control, a Ukrainian official said.
item.dc:creator: Oleksandr Chubko and Carlotta Gall
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Regional police investigators showed where Russian forces held and interrogated prisoners in a basement in Kozacha Lopan, in northern Kharkiv, Ukraine, on Thursday.

item.title: Ukraine Wants ATACMS, Long-Range Missiles the U.S. Says It Doesn’t Need
item.description: Ukrainian officials have asked for a weapon that can strike targets 190 miles away. But the Pentagon — wary of widening the war — says the ones it has provided are powerful enough.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The Pentagon’s Army Tactical Missile Systems, or ATACMS, are all reserved for top secret war plans in places like the Korean Peninsula.

item.title: Blunt Criticism of Russian Army Signals New Challenge for Putin
item.description: An official in a Russian-occupied region of Ukraine suggested Russia’s defense minister should shoot himself because of his army’s failings, an unusually blunt and public rebuke of Kremlin leadership.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: Sergei K. Shoigu, the Russian defense minister, with President Vladimir V. Putin at a commemoration of the victory over Nazi Germany in May.

item.title: Federal Judge Blocks N.Y. Gun Law, Finding Much of It Unconstitutional
item.description: The order, issued by Judge Glenn T. Suddaby, found that the state’s new restrictions on carrying guns in public trampled on the rights of New Yorkers.
item.dc:creator: Jonah E. Bromwich
item.media:description: The state’s new gun law, passed this summer, imposed elaborate restrictions on the carrying of weapons in “sensitive places,” including Times Square.

item.title: Gun-Related Suicides and Killings Continued to Rise in 2021, C.D.C. Reports
item.description: The increases in homicides were particularly stark among Black and Hispanic men, while suicides involving firearms rose among all adults.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: A vigil last year for Black lives lost to gun violence in Brooklyn.

item.title: Gunman Kills Dozens, Including Children, in Rampage at Thai Child Care Center
item.description: The 36 victims of the mass shooting included a 2-year-old child and a teacher who was eight months pregnant, the police said. They identified the gunman as a recently fired officer.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech, Muktita Suhartono, Sui-Lee Wee and Ryn Jirenuwat
item.media:description: Emergency workers carrying coffins with the bodies of victims outside a hospital in Udon Thani.

item.title: Inside the Search for the Best Mullet in America
item.description: At a qualifying event in Texas for the finals of this year’s USA Mullet Championships, 14 hopefuls competed to be the face of what many say is not just a hairstyle, but a lifestyle.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Lange
item.media:description: Joseph Bauer whipped his mullet while competing to be a finalist in this year’s contest.

item.title: Ben Sasse Plans to Resign From Senate for University of Florida Post
item.description: The second-term senator, one of seven Republicans to vote to convict former President Donald J. Trump, is in line to become president of the University of Florida.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ben Sasse, Republican of Nebraska, was previously the president of Midland University, a small private Lutheran school in his home state.

item.title: Christian Walker Battles His Father Herschel Walker
item.description: Before his Twitter posts upended the Georgia senate race, Herschel Walker’s son already had a large social media presence reveling in contradictions.
item.dc:creator: Clyde McGrady and Kellen Browning
item.media:description: Christian Walker, center, at a Los Angeles event in support of Donald Trump in 2020. He has emerged as a conservative social media star who takes delight in provoking the left, and defending Mr. Trump’s MAGA movement.

item.title: Major Mexican Government Hack Reveals Military Abuse and Spying
item.description: Hackers infiltrated the Mexican Defense Ministry, publishing millions of emails that detail the military’s growing influence over the civilian government.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the military on patrol in Celaya, Mexico.

item.title: NJ Gov. Asks Biden To Block New York’s Congestion Pricing Effort
item.description: The plan would charge drivers who enter Manhattan below 60th Street.
item.dc:creator: Tracey Tully, Ana Ley and Patrick McGeehan
item.media:credit: Michelle Gustafson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gov. Philip D. Murphy of New Jersey has said that New York’s congestion pricing proposal threatens to harm commuters from his state.

item.title: Jeremy Lin Finally Loves ‘Linsanity’ Just as Much as You Do
item.description: A star turn with the Knicks in 2012 made Lin a cultural icon. But the focus on his race — Lin is Taiwanese American — made him uncomfortable for years.
item.dc:creator: Sopan Deb
item.media:description: Jeremy Lin led the Knicks on a seven-game winning streak in February 2012, part of an exciting run known as Linsanity and chronicled in a new HBO documentary called “38 at the Garden.”

item.title: Ninety Years Ago, This Book Tried to Warn Us
item.description: A 1933 novel on the Nazi rise to power is still relevant today.
item.dc:creator: Pamela Paul
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times

item.title: Has The Fed Gone Too Far on Interest Rates?
item.description: We really don’t want the Fed to do a Lee County.
item.dc:creator: Paul Krugman
item.media:credit: Illustration by Sam Whitney/The New York Times; photograph by Javier Zayas, via Getty Images

item.title: Putin and M.B.S. Are Laughing at Us
item.description: Putin’s motivation for OPEC’s price hike is no mystery.
item.dc:creator: Thomas L. Friedman
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries

item.title: Here’s Hoping Elon Musk Destroys Twitter
item.description: The best thing the platform can do for society is implode.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Goldberg

item.title: The Triumph of the Ukrainian Idea
item.description: Only a strong liberal nationalism can defeat the authoritarians.
item.dc:creator: David Brooks

item.title: A Plan B for Democrats Living in Red States
item.description: Sometimes Democrats should not vote for Democrats.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Vowell
item.media:credit: Illustration by Shoshana Schultz/The New York Times; Photograph by Scott Raichilson via Getty

item.title: The Most Toxic Politicians Are Dragging Us to Hell With Emails and Texts
item.description: Many people once felt small-dollar, online fund-raising would save politics. Two decades later, it’s become a dangerous and awful racket.
item.dc:creator: Tim Miller

item.title: To Avoid Climate Disaster, One Task Is More Urgent Than Anything Else
item.description: Nearly 1,000 new coal-fired power plants are planned around the world. We should not be building any.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Curtin
item.media:description: A state-owned coal-fired power plant in southern China.

item.title: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen and Jessica Cheung
item.media:description: Demonstrators outside the White House in 2016 calling for the legalization of marijuana.

item.title: ‘The Run-Up’: Can Democrats Catch up to Years of Republican Unity?
item.description: The overturning of Roe v. Wade has given Democrats a rallying issue to mobilize around before the midterms. Can they catch up to years of Republican unity?
item.dc:creator: ‘The Run-Up’ Team
item.media:credit: Emil Lippe for The New York Times

item.title: Have You Changed How You Shop and Where You Dine? We Want To Hear About It.
item.description: Higher food prices are changing people’s behaviors at the grocery store and in restaurants. Let us know how they have affected you.
item.dc:creator: Julie Creswell
item.media:credit: Celeste Noche for The New York Times
item.media:description: A trip to the grocery store is more expensive than it was two years ago.

item.title: ‘Hard Fork’: A New Technology Podcast from The New York Times
item.description: A weekly look at the future that’s already here. Listen to the trailer of our new tech podcast.
item.dc:creator: The ‘Hard Fork’ Team

item.title: Judge Grants Elon Musk’s Request to Delay Trial With Twitter
item.description: A judge in Delaware gave Mr. Musk until Oct. 28 to complete the deal. The trial, which was set to start in a little more than a week, could still happen in November.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch and Kate Conger
item.media:description: A judge has granted Elon Musk’s request to delay a trial that was set to start on Oct. 17.

item.title: Police Vehicle Crashes Into Crowd in Bronx, Critically Injuring 2
item.description: The vehicle drove over a double yellow line, hit a car and careened onto the sidewalk, sending 10 people to the hospital, including two children, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack and Téa Kvetenadze
item.media:credit: David Dee Delgado for The New York Times
item.media:description: A police vehicle crashed into a crowd of pedestrians in the Bronx.

item.title: Witness in Oath Keepers Sedition Trial Says Leader Promoted Violent Approach
item.description: “It sounded like we were going to war against the United States government,” a former member of the militia group testified.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of President Donald J. Trump protesting the election results in Washington in November 2020. Members of the Oath Keepers militia group discussed bringing weapons to a rally that month.

item.title: France Seeks to Weather an Energy Crisis as Russia Cuts Gas Supplies
item.description: The government unveiled its biggest energy conservation measures in decades, part of an effort in Europe to save power as Russia cuts gas supplies.
item.dc:creator: Liz Alderman
item.media:credit: Joao Luiz Bulcao/Hans Lucas, Via Reuters
item.media:description: The Eiffel Tower will have its lights turned off more than an hour earlier each night as part of an effort by Paris’s mayor, Anne Hidalgo, to reduce the city’s electricity bill.

item.title: Surf and the City
item.description: Autumn may be the season of big swells, but the smaller waves found year-round near East Coast cities are perfect for beginners who want to give surfing a try.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Fogarty
item.media:credit: Yuvraj Khanna for The New York Times

item.title: Balance Exercises to Improve Your Strength
item.description: This simple, often neglected skill can pay huge dividends later in life.
item.dc:creator: Hilary Achauer
item.media:credit: Sarah Karlan for The New York Times

item.title: 6 Ways to Level Up Your Daily Walk
item.description: Experts say Americans are taking more walks than before the pandemic. Here are some ways to turn your neighborhood stroll in to an exciting workout.
item.dc:creator: Emily Pennington
item.media:credit: Yana Paskova for The New York Times

item.title: Pull-Up Techniques for Everyone
item.description: The trick is to break the movement into pieces and train with patience and deliberateness.
item.dc:creator: Christie Aschwanden
item.media:credit: Ben Rayner for The New York Times
item.media:description: “It’s a simple exercise that’s really hard to do,” said Chilasa King, a New York powerlifter and coach. But doing them is “an amazing feeling.”

item.title: What is 'Body Neutrality' and Can It Change Your Work Out?
item.description: The key to staying active long term may be to care less about how you look and more about how you feel.
item.dc:creator: Charlotte Cowles
item.media:credit: Illustration by Yang Kim; Photographs by Getty Images

item.title: In Annie Ernaux, a Nobel Laureate Who Plumbs Her Own Passions
item.description: The French writer, who was awarded the 2022 Nobel Prize in Literature, blurs the line between fiction and memoir with spare prose she has characterized as “brutally direct.”
item.dc:creator: Dwight Garner
item.media:description: “The world is made to be pounced on and enjoyed,” Annie Ernaux has written. “There is absolutely no reason at all to hold back.”

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
